text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Program Scope and Objectives and its related subsections to comply with the Deputy Commissioners of Services and Enforcement and Operations Support memo dated September 14, 2016 entitled, “Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity and Understanding of Internal Controls,” are added in new section 8.20.3.1.
Links to other IRM chapters, Exhibits, Form and Documents were added.
This IRM supersedes the information in IRM 8.20.3 Account and Processing Support, Appeals Database System (ACDS), dated October 15, 2014.
AUDIENCE
Appeals
Table of Contents
Database System (ACDS)
) Purpose. This IRM section explains the terms and processes used to track, and control cases in Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS). (
) Audience. Appeals Account and Processing Support (APS) Employees. (
) Policy Owner. Appeals Policy is under the Director of Case and Operations Support. (
) Program Owner. Appeals Policy is the program office responsible for technical and procedural guidance to the Appeals Organization and is the Director of Policy, Planning, Quality & Analysis. (

) Contact Information. Appeals employees follow established procedures on to Contact an Analyst. All other employees should contact the Product Owner provided on the Product Catalog Information page for this IRM. (
) ACDS is a computerized case control system used to control and track throughout the appeal process. (

) Information input into ACDS is used as follows: a. To control cases during the unassigned period. b. To control and track cases in inventory until ﬁnal closing. c. To monitor statutes. d. To record key actions taken as the case moves through the appeal process. e. To record Appeals Technical Employee (ATE), Appeals Account tion Specialist (AARS), and APS time applied to cases, status of etc. f. To automate the process of changing, updating and modifying g. To improve statute control and data accuracy. (
) IRM
, Account and Processing Support (APS), establishes the APS program and policy framework for Appeals. (

) The Director, Case and Operations Support (COS) is the executive for designing, developing, delivering, and monitoring short- and long-range administration policies, programs, strategies, and objectives for the Appeals organization. (

) The Director, Policy, Planning, Quality and Analysis, is responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to Appeals employees, ing and maintaining policies and standard procedures for Appeals work streams. (
) Policy is comprised of two teams of analysts: Collection Policy and tion Policy. The analyst(s) responsible for APS programs report to the for Collection Policy. (
) The Policy analyst shown on the Product Catalog page as the originator is assigned author of this IRM. (

) For more information on Appeals Policy, see the About Appeals - Case and Operations Support (COS) page on the Appeals website, where you can navigate to the two Policy teams’ web pages. Internal Revenue Manual
Centralized Database System (ACDS) 8.20.3
Purpose. This IRM section explains the terms and processes used to establish, track, and control cases in Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS).
Account and Processing Support (

) The Director, APS, is the senior manager responsible for the control and pro- cessing of all Appeals cases. The Director, APS, reports to the Director COS. For more information on APS, see the APS page on the Appeals website. (

) APS has primary responsibility for the following: • Receiving, controlling and processing ACDS and other update requests from the ATE and Counsel Attorney. • Mailing closing letters prepared by the technical employee when priate. • Verifying and updating Assessment Statute Expiration Dates (ASED) each taxpayer’s account in Appeals’ or Counsel’s jurisdiction. • Processing and monitoring ﬁnal account adjustment processing based upon the disposition of the case to ensure the correct billing notice or refund is released to protect the taxpayer’s right to ﬁnality for their re- spective case. • Identifying account adjustment errors and/or unpostable conditions expeditiously performing corrective actions to ensure the taxpayer’s account is accurate and resolved. • Adherence to the Appeals Feedback Loop requirements based upon case type. (

) ACDS combines various database systems into one centralized web-based system. Although each area retains “ownership” of its cases, a centralized Centralized repository is shared and various data ﬁelds become available to each part of System the system that needs the information. By using a centralized data the functionality from all sub-systems is integrated into a single application all users. (
) The database can only be accessed using an IRS computer. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) ACDS combines various database systems into one centralized web-based system. Although each area retains “ownership” of its cases, a centralized data repository is shared and various data ﬁelds become available to each part of the system that needs the information. By using a centralized data repository, the functionality from all sub-systems is integrated into a single application for all users. (
) The database can only be accessed using an IRS computer.
Additional APS program information and resources are available at https:// portal.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/ap/Pages/COS/APS/Default.aspx

Centralized Database System (ACDS) 8.20.3
) ACDS is a role based application and your role will determine which permis- sions you have in the system. To request access to ACDS, you must submit On Line
(OL
). Your ACDS account name will reﬂect your official name as shown on the OL
system unless you have an officially desig- nated pseudonym as veriﬁed by the Discovery Directory. (

) APS employees will have access to a variety of functions to enable them to their job, based on the permissions authorized by their manager. Employees may be authorized to log on to ACDS and access different offices. The following is a listing of the functions that are available to APS employees if missions have been granted: • CASES - allows an APS Tax Examiner (TE) to establish, update, transfer, close, etc. a case in ACDS • PERSONNEL - allows an employee to update his/her personnel ﬁle. • DIMS - Docket Information Management System - allows access to DIMS which is the system used by APS to identify Tax Court cases monitor them until they are received in Appeals and updated on • APS - provides access to the Processing Employee Automated (PEAS), which is the inventory and timekeeping system used by APS • APGOLF - provides the ability to generate forms and letters using taxpayer data found in ACDS • AMATCH - allows access to generate various types of validation for the Audit Information Management System (AIMS) and the Spouse Tracking System (ISTS) • PCS - Partnership Control System - allows access to generate PCS reports • REPORTS - allows access to various reports, transmittal Form
and case summary cards • ADMIN - allows an employee to perform various administrative if permissions have been granted (

) These additional functions are available to all ACDS users: • Home - returns the user to the ACDS home page and identiﬁes the user’s home area in relationship to the Field and Campus Areas • ACDS Memos - allows access to all ACDS memorandums that have

may be authorized to log on to ACDS and access different offices. The following is a listing of the functions that are available to APS employees if missions have been granted: • CASES - allows an APS Tax Examiner (TE) to establish, update, transfer, close, etc. a case in ACDS • PERSONNEL - allows an employee to update his/her personnel ﬁle. • DIMS - Docket Information Management System - allows access to DIMS which is the system used by APS to identify Tax Court cases monitor them until they are received in Appeals and updated on • APS - provides access to the Processing Employee Automated (PEAS), which is the inventory and timekeeping system used by APS • APGOLF - provides the ability to generate forms and letters using taxpayer data found in ACDS • AMATCH - allows access to generate various types of validation for the Audit Information Management System (AIMS) and the Spouse Tracking System (ISTS) • PCS - Partnership Control System - allows access to generate PCS reports • REPORTS - allows access to various reports, transmittal Form
and case summary cards • ADMIN - allows an employee to perform various administrative if permissions have been granted (

) These additional functions are available to all ACDS users: • Home - returns the user to the ACDS home page and identiﬁes the user’s home area in relationship to the Field and Campus Areas • ACDS Memos - allows access to all ACDS memorandums that have been issued • SEARCH - allows an employee to search the ACDS open or closed database using various options, such as Taxpayer Identiﬁcation (TIN), Taxpayer Name (TPName), i.e. TIN, TPName, docket number, etc. • Utilities - This function has a variety of selections, such as a statute date computation, number of days, target date, Julian date,
SN Expiration, Name/Use

D Lookup and Forms/Letters • Print- prints the current screen • Validation - allows APS and ATEs to update critical data ﬁelds and change the statute date, statute code, and tax period. • Validation Tracking Log - shows all updates that have been input validated. • LOGOUT - a security requirement for employees to log out when ACDS.

) A new WUNO will be established for premature referrals when returned to originating function. (

) Enter the primary TIN in the ﬁrst TIN ﬁeld. This number is the Social Number (SSN) or Employee Identiﬁcation Number (EIN) of the primary taxpayer shown from documents in the administrative ﬁle such as the tax return, AIMS print , etc. (
) Enter TIN
with the SSN of the secondary taxpayer on the account, such when a joint returned is ﬁled. (
) Special instructions apply for innocent spouse and non-petitioning spouse cases. See IRM
for innocent spouse carding information and IRM
for non-petitioning spouse carding information. (

) Unique modiﬁers are sometimes added to the TIN to identify special cases. They are as follows: • N - used to identify non-master ﬁle cases • P - used to identify an Employee Plan (EP) revocation case • V - used to identify estate and gift tax cases • A through J - used to allow multiple use of TINs within the same (

) The following modiﬁers are systemically (computer) generated based on an action taken on ACDS: • R - used to identify a reassigned case • S - used to identify a reject • T - used to identify a transfer in case Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) For Collection Due Process Offer in Compromise (CDP OIC) cases, enter date the new WUNO was assigned to the ATE. (
) If the AO ﬁeld is blank, this item is bypassed. (
) This date remains constant throughout the appeal process. (
) For non-docketed cases: a. CDP cases: REQAPPL ﬁeld is a required entry for all CDP cases. REQAPPL date can be found on Form
for ﬁeld CDP cases on page
(the
th column) or on Form
-B, box
, for ACS cases. • Type DPLN = Due Process Lien • Type DPLV = Due Process Levy • Type DPL
= Due Process Lien and Levy b. Offer in Compromise cases: REQAPPL date is the postmark date of taxpayer’s request for appeal. c. CDP-OIC cases: the REQAPPL date is the earliest date the Form
was date stamped as received by the Internal Revenue Service. The Increase Prevention and Reconciliation Act (TIPRA) statute will two years from this date. See IRM
for additional regarding the TIPRA statute date. d. Potential defaulted OIC cases: REQAPPL date is the date from Form

, Courtesy Investigation. e. For all other non-docketed cases where the appeal request is written: • REQAPPL date is the date of the appeal request. • If the request is undated, REQAPPL is the postmark date. • If the request is undated and the postmark date is not available or legible, REQAPPL is the date the request was received. f. For non-docketed cases where the appeal request is verbal and is mented in the administrative ﬁle: REQAPPL is date of the appeal g. If there is no documentation in the ﬁle, this item should be left blank.
(04-20-2021) REQAPPL (Request Appeal - Date Taxpayer Requested Appeal)
Offer in Compromise cases: REQAPPL date is the postmark date of the taxpayer’s request for appeal. CDP-OIC cases: the REQAPPL date is the earliest date the Form
was date stamped as received by the Internal Revenue Service. The Increase Prevention and Reconciliation Act (TIPRA) statute will be two years from this date. See IRM
for additional information regarding the TIPRA statute date. Potential defaulted OIC cases: REQAPPL date is the date from Form
, Courtesy Investigation. For all other non-docketed cases where the appeal request is written:

REQAPPL date is the date of the appeal request. If the request is undated, REQAPPL is the postmark date. If the request is undated and the postmark date is not available or legible, REQAPPL is the date the request was received.

For non-docketed cases where the appeal request is verbal and is docu- mented in the administrative ﬁle: REQAPPL is date of the appeal request. If there is no documentation in the ﬁle, this item should be left blank.

) For docketed cases, enter the date the petition was ﬁled in the REQAPPL (

) This ﬁeld is a required entry as indicated above. (
) For Offer in Compromise (OIC) cases, the RECDATE is date the case was received in Appeals. (
) For CDP-OIC cases, the RECDATE is the date the ATE’s request for a new CDP-OIC WUNO was received in APS. (

) For RECDATE ﬁeld of all other appeal requests, enter the date the tive ﬁle was received in Appeals. This date should remain constant the appeal process with the exception of the following information for the Received Date on docketed cases. Note: See IRM

for additional information on the Received Date for docketed cases. If the original administrative ﬁle is received before ASGNDATE is input, change the RECDATE to the date the administrative ﬁle is received in Appeals.Iftheoriginal administrative ﬁle is received after ASGNDATE is input, the RECDATE to the same date as ASGNDATE. This practice creates a more accurate P
measure.

measure.

The docket number can be obtained from various documents in the tive ﬁle such as the TLCATS screen print and also on DIMS.

This ﬁeld is to be completed only on docketed cases. Enter the name of the Counsel Attorney assigned to the case, last name ﬁrst.
For Estate Tax cases, use the date of death in YYYYMM format for this ﬁeld.
Additional information regarding entering representative information into

IF: THEN: Form 2848 is included in the ad- Enter the name of the taxpayer’s ministrative ﬁle representative from the Form 2848 If CFINK is included in the admin- Enter the name of the attorney of istrative ﬁle record

IF: THEN: If both Form 2848 and CFINK are Determine which date is more included in the administrative ﬁle current and enter that information on ACDS. If you are unable to determine which information is more current, then alert the ATE. If the case is DOCKETED Enter the attorney of record as shown on the Tax Court petition. Please note the attorney of record may not match the repre- sentative information shown on the Form 2848. When unsure, alert the ATE.
Note: If Form 8821 is present in the administrative ﬁle, annotate this in the NOTES ﬁeld on ACDS.
Enter the name of the second representative if it is available from information in the administrative ﬁle.

8.20 Account and Processing Support (APS)
) This ﬁeld is updated via the ATE case activity record (CARATS). (
) It represents the total direct hours expended on the WUNO. (
) This ﬁeld contains the date the acknowledgement or substitute ment letter is generated. (
) The entry is systemically entered at the time the letter is generated by the ATE, ATM, or ATM Secretary. (

) Enter the correct AIMS indicator code for all cases as follows: a. Y = Yes, return should be controlled on AIMS and is on AIMS at the of receipt. An AMDISA print should be included in the administrative b. N = No, return should be controlled on AIMS but is not on AIMS at the time of receipt. IDRS Command Code AM

A is used by Appeals to establish the AIMS control. c. E = Exempt, return should NOT be controlled on AIMS and no AIMS controls were established at the time of receipt. There are no AIMS controls for CDP, OIC, penalty appeals, trust fund recovery penalty cases, abatement of interest claims, campus disallowed claims, etc. Note: The AMATCH validation program is keyed to these codes. It is very important to use them correctly to avoid having cases on the IVL lists lessly, meaning if the match program reads “E”, the AIMS listing will not be searched. See IRM
for additional information regarding the AMATCH reports.

) When an ATE inputs a change to the statute-critical data ﬁelds of tax period, statute date, or statute code, the entry will trigger the Statute Validation System (SVS). When the original return is received on a case with a tax modiﬁer, the tax period must be updated in the SVS via the AIVP Validation Menu (which is accessible from the CAR or the Case Summary Card). All changes in SVS for the tax period critical data ﬁeld is considered a Normal Update (N). Once the validation is submitted, ACDS will be updated and an automatic entry of VA (Validation Accepted) will be made in the CAR. (

) If the APS Tax Examiner is requested to remove a tax period from ACDS because it is not part of the case, the APS Tax Examiner MUST CONSIDER THE STATUTE IMPLICATIONS AND UPDATE ALL APPLICABLE DATABASE SUCH AS IDRS, AIMS, AOIC, etc. (
) Next to each tax period, enter the expiration date of the statutory period for assessment. If there is an open statute (live or non-assessed), the date must be entered. (

) When an ATE inputs a change to the statute-critical data ﬁelds of tax period, statute date, or statute code, the entry will trigger the Statute Validation System (SVS). All changes must be designated as either a Normal Update or an Error Correction (E). Once the validation is submitted, ACDS will be updated and an automatic entry of VA (Validation Accepted) will be made in CAR. (

) Enter the appropriate code to denote the special period of limitations. Remember, if there is a valid statute code, it must be entered. See IRM
for a complete listing of all valid statute codes. (

) When an ATE inputs a change to the statute-critical data ﬁelds of tax statute date, or statute code, the entry will trigger the Statute Validation System (SVS). All changes must be designated as either a Normal Update or an Error Correction (E). Once the validation is submitted, ACDS will be updated and an automatic entry of VA (Validation Accepted) will be made in CAR. (
) Follow the rules below to determine the code: a. If the period of limitations is extended by special consent Form
–A Special Consent to Extend the Time to Assess Tax, enter

–A. b. In bankruptcy cases, enter BKRUP. However, the actual statute date must remain in the “statute date” ﬁeld. c. If the statutory period for assessment has expired and the year is only by reason of the ﬁling of a claim, enter the word CLAIM. d. If the statutory period for assessment has expired and the return is only because of the assertion of a fraud penalty, enter the FRAUD. • If the statutory period for assessment has not expired in a year for which there is an assertion of a fraud penalty, the open statute date must also be entered. e. If the return being established is docketed before the tax court, enter DOCKT. f. If there is an omission from gross income which is in excess of
% of the gross income stated on the return, enter
E. • If there is a valid open statute date, the statute date ﬁeld must be completed with the statute date. • If the statute date has expired and the case is being held open only the

E issue, the statute date ﬁeld must be completed with the year statute date. g. 8.20 Account and Processing Support (APS)
How to control the statute where there is an open ASED for the Net Operating Loss (NOL) year(s) which carries back to years where the statute is only open resulting from the CB:

Tax Period Statute Statute Comments Date Code 201012 CBYYYYMM • Open only on a = carryback CB201212 • The YYYYMM iden- tiﬁes the year with the open statute • No statute date will be entered 200912 CB201212 • Open only on a carryback 201212 04/15/2016 • No code would be entered as this is the NOL year where the CB comes from
How to control the statute when the CB years have open ASEDs but are also covered by the NOL:
